section.title: Units and Dimensional Analysis
section.p:
The evolution operator is dimensionless: U(-\infty,\infty) = T\exp\left({i\over\hbar}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\d^4 x \L(x) \right)
So:
\left[\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\d^4 x \L(x) \right] = [\hbar] = M^0
where M is an arbitrary mass scale. Length unit is M^{-1}, so then
[\L(x)] = M^4
For the particular forms of the Lagrangians above we get:
[m\bar ee] = [m^2 Z_\mu Z^\mu] = [m^2 H^2] = [i\bar e\gamma^\mu\partial_\mu e] = [\L] = M^4
so [\bar ee] = M^3, [Z_\mu Z^\mu]=[H^2] = M^2 and we get [e] = [\bar e] = M^{3\over2} [Z_\mu] = [Z^\mu] = [H] = [\partial_\mu] = [\partial^\mu] = M^1

In order to get the above units from the SI units, one has to do the following identification: kg	o M^1 m	o M^{-1} s	o M^{-1} A	o M^1 The SI units of the above quantities are: [\phi] = m V={kg\,m^2\over A\,s^3}=M [A_\mu]={[\phi]\over [c]}=m{V\,s\over m} = {kg\, m\over A\,s^2}=M [c]=m {m\over s} = 1 [e]=m C = A\, s=1 [\hbar]=m J\,s = {m^2\,kg\over s}=1 [\partial_\mu]=m {1\over m}=M [F_{\mu
u}]=[\partial_\mu A_
u]=m {kg\over A\,s^2}=M^2 [\L]=[F_{\mu
u}]^2=m {kg^2\over A^2\,s^4}=M^4 [\psi]=m {kg^{1\over2}\over A\,m\,s}=M^{3\over2} The SI units are useful for checking that the c, e and \hbar constants are at correct places in the expression.
